content.raw: so I guess relative paths won't work when the source comes from a `data-string`?
content.html: so I guess relative paths won't work when the source comes from a data-string?

content.raw:
No they won't, which is unfortunate but I can't think of a workaround. I think the reason we haven't had issues with relative paths inside COLLADA and OBJ files before is that we never load those files from strings - they always must come from a file on disk. I don't think it would be a good idea to enforce that for SDF though.

I like your idea of at least printing more informative warnings mentioning that a relative path may not have worked because the SDF was loaded from a string.
content.html:
No they won't, which is unfortunate but I can't think of a workaround. I think the reason we haven't had issues with relative paths inside COLLADA and OBJ files before is that we never load those files from strings - they always must come from a file on disk. I don't think it would be a good idea to enforce that for SDF though.

I like your idea of at least printing more informative warnings mentioning that a relative path may not have worked because the SDF was loaded from a string.

content.raw:
so this works with the EntityFactory by passing an sdf string with an `<include>` tag:

~~~
'<sdf version=\"1.6\">'\
'<include>'\
'<uri>https://fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/1.0/chapulina/models/actor - relative paths</uri>'\
'</include>'\
'</sdf>" '
~~~

I think it wouldn't work if you read the model file to a string and pass the string. I don't know how common that use case is, but it would be good to have helpful error messages like "this model uses relative paths and requires a file path" or something. Or do we need an attribute saying relative paths are being used?

~~~
                <geometry>
                    <mesh>
                        <uri relative_path="true">meshes/some_mesh.dae</uri>
                    </mesh>
                </geometry>
~~~
content.html:

'</include>'\
'</sdf>" '

I think it wouldn't work if you read the model file to a string and pass the string. I don't know how common that use case is, but it would be good to have helpful error messages like "this model uses relative paths and requires a file path" or something. Or do we need an attribute saying relative paths are being used?

                <geometry>
                    <mesh>
                        <uri relative_path="true">meshes/some_mesh.dae</uri>
                    </mesh>
                </geometry>

I think the user should already be getting some warning that the path was not found. We could try to make it more informative mentioning the relative path.

The `relative_path` attribute seems a bit redundant to me, since we can detect that from the URI pattern, no?

I think the user should already be getting some warning that the path was not found. We could try to make it more informative mentioning the relative path.

content.raw:
yeah, the attribute isn't needed, but `meshes/some_mesh.dae` isn't really a URI because it doesn't start with `scheme:`. So perhaps we use the following?

~~~
<uri>relative_path://meshes/some_mesh.dae</uri>
~~~
content.html:
yeah, the attribute isn't needed, but meshes/some_mesh.dae isn't really a URI because it doesn't start with scheme:. So perhaps we use the following?

<uri>relative_path://meshes/some_mesh.dae</uri>

content.raw: Oh you're right, I don't think it would be an official "URI". I'm not sure what issue the extra `relative_path://` scheme is trying to fix though. My first impulse is not to add a new scheme that needs to be learned, since the use of relative paths is quite common in different applications and should be easier to look and know what it means.
content.html: Oh you're right, I don't think it would be an official "URI". I'm not sure what issue the extra relative_path:// scheme is trying to fix though. My first impulse is not to add a new scheme that needs to be learned, since the use of relative paths is quite common in different applications and should be easier to look and know what it means.

content.raw:
it's not a URI without a scheme, and it's easier to detect when relative paths are in use if they declare themselves as such

`path://` is shorter

also, scheme's can't have `_` characters https://stackoverflow.com/a/9142331/7179595
content.html:
it's not a URI without a scheme, and it's easier to detect when relative paths are in use if they declare themselves as such

path:// is shorter

also, scheme's can't have _ characters https://stackoverflow.com/a/9142331/7179595

content.raw:
I don't know, it still feels odd to me to come up with a new scheme just for this. I feel like there must be a more standard way of handling relative paths, I'm doing some research. From web files, to any files dealing with UNIX systems, a path like `meshes/some_mesh.dae` would be treated like a relative path. Maybe I'm just missing the formal way of describing it?

We already support `<uri>/home/user/...</uri>`, would we stop supporting that because it doesn't have a scheme?
content.html:
I don't know, it still feels odd to me to come up with a new scheme just for this. I feel like there must be a more standard way of handling relative paths, I'm doing some research. From web files, to any files dealing with UNIX systems, a path like meshes/some_mesh.dae would be treated like a relative path. Maybe I'm just missing the formal way of describing it?

We already support <uri>/home/user/...</uri>, would we stop supporting that because it doesn't have a scheme?

content.raw: I would suggest using `<uri>file:///home/user/...</uri>`
content.html: I would suggest using <uri>file:///home/user/...</uri>

content.raw: I also thought that was allowed, but [apparently](https://stackoverflow.com/a/15193744) it isn't!

wow

content.raw:
I don't want to derail this, but it just seems weird to me that the content of the `<uri>` tag would not be a URI, since a scheme is required

and [wikipedia says](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File_URI_scheme#How_many_slashes?) `file://relative/path` is not valid according to [RFC8089](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8089) but lots of people do it anyway

so we could follow the crowd and misuse `file:`, use a different scheme like `path:` or just use a non-URI string with no scheme
content.html:
I don't want to derail this, but it just seems weird to me that the content of the <uri> tag would not be a URI, since a scheme is required

and wikipedia says file://relative/path is not valid according to RFC8089 but lots of people do it anyway

so we could follow the crowd and misuse file:, use a different scheme like path: or just use a non-URI string with no scheme

content.raw: I'm ok with `file://rel/path.dae`. I'll make the changes :thumbsup: Thanks for iterating!
content.html: I'm ok with file://rel/path.dae. I'll make the changes Thanks for iterating!

content.raw: thanks for your patience!
content.html: thanks for your patience!

content.raw:
So, there's a problem with this. Gazebo-classic currently accepts substituting `file://` for `GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH`. This is how `<uri>file://media/materials/scripts/gazebo.material</uri>` works, for example. So interpreting it as a relative path would break Gazebo compatibility. I also noticed several ROS packages use this pattern.

So I'm standing behind my original proposal, and now with some formal backing:

* From [RFC 2396](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2396):
    * _"Relative addressing of URI allows document trees to be partially independent of their location and access scheme."_ - that's what we want
    * _"Relative URI references are distinguished from absolute URI in that they do not begin with a scheme name."_ - that's what this PR supports
    * _"A relative reference beginning with a single slash character is termed an absolute-path reference"_ - that's already supported by SDF
* From [XML Schema 1.0](http://www.datypic.com/sc/xsd/t-xsd_anyURI.html)'s `xsd::anyURI` docs:
    * _"Relative URIs are specified as the difference from a base URI, such as ../prod.html."_

---

## Fun facts

* Gazebo-classic has `materials/textures` hardcoded internally, which allows COLLADA files like [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/src/e6d645674e8a99cb7955ce3b9a1fbe26c58c41f2/cardboard_box/meshes/cardboard_box.dae#lines-143) and OBJ files like [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/src/e6d645674e8a99cb7955ce3b9a1fbe26c58c41f2/suv/meshes/suv.mtl#lines-29) to refer to their textures just by the filename without any path.

* Both Gazebo-classic and Ignition support relative paths within COLLADA files like [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/src/e6d645674e8a99cb7955ce3b9a1fbe26c58c41f2/hinged_door/meshes/door.dae#lines-949) and OBJ files like [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/src/e6d645674e8a99cb7955ce3b9a1fbe26c58c41f2/cloverleaf_interchange/meshes/cloverleaf.mtl#lines-15).
content.html:
So, there's a problem with this. Gazebo-classic currently accepts substituting file:// for GAZEBO_RESOURCE_PATH. This is how <uri>file://media/materials/scripts/gazebo.material</uri> works, for example. So interpreting it as a relative path would break Gazebo compatibility. I also noticed several ROS packages use this pattern.

So I'm standing behind my original proposal, and now with some formal backing:

  • From RFC 2396:
    • "Relative addressing of URI allows document trees to be partially independent of their location and access scheme." - that's what we want
    • "Relative URI references are distinguished from absolute URI in that they do not begin with a scheme name." - that's what this PR supports
    • "A relative reference beginning with a single slash character is termed an absolute-path reference" - that's already supported by SDF
  • From XML Schema 1.0's xsd::anyURI docs:
    • "Relative URIs are specified as the difference from a base URI, such as ../prod.html."

Fun facts

  • Gazebo-classic has materials/textures hardcoded internally, which allows COLLADA files like this and OBJ files like this to refer to their textures just by the filename without any path.

  • Both Gazebo-classic and Ignition support relative paths within COLLADA files like this and OBJ files like this.

content.raw: Would it make sense to create another similarly named function to get the URI with the file path prepended? Alternatively, we can have `Uri` take a bool argument with a default value to specify whether the user wants the text in the `<uri>` tag or the resolved file path, with the default being the text in the `<uri>` tag. I know this means we have to modify ign-gazebo and osrf/gazebo, but I would be okay with that. I just don't know if the DOM object is supposed to be doing these kind of manipulations without being explicitly told to do so.
content.html: Would it make sense to create another similarly named function to get the URI with the file path prepended? Alternatively, we can have Uri take a bool argument with a default value to specify whether the user wants the text in the <uri> tag or the resolved file path, with the default being the text in the <uri> tag. I know this means we have to modify ign-gazebo and osrf/gazebo, but I would be okay with that. I just don't know if the DOM object is supposed to be doing these kind of manipulations without being explicitly told to do so.

content.raw: I think some relevant context is that we have been discussing a similar issue with the `Pose()` accessors in several DOM classes, and what they should return once we add the new frame semantics. I think there's a philosophical / design aspect to the question
content.html: I think some relevant context is that we have been discussing a similar issue with the Pose() accessors in several DOM classes, and what they should return once we add the new frame semantics. I think there's a philosophical / design aspect to the question

content.raw:
we added `Element::FilePath` and `Element::SetFilePath` as bare accessors but `Element::StringAsFullPath` as the smart function

I think it's definitely more convenient to keep the existing API for Mesh and Actor
content.html:
we added Element::FilePath and Element::SetFilePath as bare accessors but Element::StringAsFullPath as the smart function

I think it's definitely more convenient to keep the existing API for Mesh and Actor

content.raw: another option is to add another API that provides the raw value, and let `Mesh::Uri` be the smart API. that would minimize downstream effects on gazebo
content.html: another option is to add another API that provides the raw value, and let Mesh::Uri be the smart API. that would minimize downstream effects on gazebo

content.raw: I can go either way. If we're striving for the class API to be as close to the spec as possible, I think using `Uri` for the raw value would be more appropriate.
content.html: I can go either way. If we're striving for the class API to be as close to the spec as possible, I think using Uri for the raw value would be more appropriate.

content.raw:
Yeah that would be one way to work around the concern I had above that *SDFormat shouldn't be changing the URI value and instead just reading it and passing it along*, without adding a `Mesh::FilePath` function and having to change `ign-msgs`. I can add `FullPathUri` functions and leave `Uri`s untouched, so the `SDF->msgs` conversion in `ign-gazebo` can use that and ignore `Uri`. How does that sound?

Another option is just to go with `Mesh::FilePath`, which is cleaner and potentially more helpful in my opinion, but also change `msgs` and target this at Citadel.
content.html:
Yeah that would be one way to work around the concern I had above that SDFormat shouldn't be changing the URI value and instead just reading it and passing it along, without adding a Mesh::FilePath function and having to change ign-msgs. I can add FullPathUri functions and leave Uris untouched, so the SDF->msgs conversion in ign-gazebo can use that and ignore Uri. How does that sound?

Another option is just to go with Mesh::FilePath, which is cleaner and potentially more helpful in my opinion, but also change msgs and target this at Citadel.

content.raw:
> I can add FullPathUri functions and leave Uris untouched, so the SDF->msgs conversion in ign-gazebo can use that and ignore Uri. How does that sound?

I like that. The `SDF->msgs` conversion is in a downstream application and so `ign-gazebo` can choose to put the resolved path there. I'm not sure if the serialized message needs to maintain the relative path and the `filepath`. Maybe there's a use case I'm not thinking about.
content.html:
I can add FullPathUri functions and leave Uris untouched, so the SDF->msgs conversion in ign-gazebo can use that and ignore Uri. How does that sound?

I like that. The SDF->msgs conversion is in a downstream application and so ign-gazebo can choose to put the resolved path there. I'm not sure if the serialized message needs to maintain the relative path and the filepath. Maybe there's a use case I'm not thinking about.

content.raw: one use case would be trying to serialize the DOM objects back to an XML document and have them match the original exactly, but I'm not sure that is realistic or even a goal for us
content.html: one use case would be trying to serialize the DOM objects back to an XML document and have them match the original exactly, but I'm not sure that is realistic or even a goal for us

content.raw: Since we have a `Mesh::SetUri` member, we'd need to store the file path within `Mesh` to reconstruct the `FullPathUri` when a new URI is set. So I think it's just cleaner to expose `Mesh::FilePath` and `ign-gazebo` can combine that with URI as it sees fit for internal use.
content.html: Since we have a Mesh::SetUri member, we'd need to store the file path within Mesh to reconstruct the FullPathUri when a new URI is set. So I think it's just cleaner to expose Mesh::FilePath and ign-gazebo can combine that with URI as it sees fit for internal use.

content.raw: Looks good to me! Left a couple of minor questions. Also, is the statement about this PR breaking relative paths in ign gazebo still true?
content.html: Looks good to me! Left a couple of minor questions. Also, is the statement about this PR breaking relative paths in ign gazebo still true?

content.raw: I'm unapproving because I just started looking into how ign-gazebo might use `Mesh::FilePath` and encountered what I think might be a roadblock. In the current implementation, resources are fetched via a callback function which doesn't have access to the `FilePath` of the containing object. I haven't delved into it yet, but thought we should hold off till we have a clear way of implementing it in ign-gazebo.
content.html: I'm unapproving because I just started looking into how ign-gazebo might use Mesh::FilePath and encountered what I think might be a roadblock. In the current implementation, resources are fetched via a callback function which doesn't have access to the FilePath of the containing object. I haven't delved into it yet, but thought we should hold off till we have a clear way of implementing it in ign-gazebo.

content.raw: Okay, I think meshes are fine. The problem is with `<include><uri>` tags because the included file has to be found by the parser when calling `Root::Load` before DOM objects are created. We might have to pass in the `FilePath` as a second argument to the `findFile` callback. Addressing this seems to be out of scope for this PR so I'll go ahead and approve.
content.html: Okay, I think meshes are fine. The problem is with <include><uri> tags because the included file has to be found by the parser when calling Root::Load before DOM objects are created. We might have to pass in the FilePath as a second argument to the findFile callback. Addressing this seems to be out of scope for this PR so I'll go ahead and approve.

content.raw:
Do you have a way of reproducing the issue you're talking about? Using `<include><uri>` in [this world](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/433/handle-relative-uris/diff#chg-examples/worlds/fuel.sdf) works for me.

Or maybe you're talking about having a relative path within `<include><uri>` itself? Such as loading a model relative to the path of the world file? If so, yes, I think it currently doesn't work and we could address this later.
content.html:
Do you have a way of reproducing the issue you're talking about? Using <include><uri> in this world works for me.

Or maybe you're talking about having a relative path within <include><uri> itself? Such as loading a model relative to the path of the world file? If so, yes, I think it currently doesn't work and we could address this later.

content.raw: I think it's still true. Before, you could have a relative path for a mesh and if the file existed w.r.t. the path you're running `ign gazebo` from, that would work. Now it will use the path relative to the model file path.
content.html: I think it's still true. Before, you could have a relative path for a mesh and if the file existed w.r.t. the path you're running ign gazebo from, that would work. Now it will use the path relative to the model file path.
